title: Andres F. Ramirez-Mejia
text:
Hi!
I’m a PhD candidate in Biological Science at the National University of Tucuman in Argentina. I was born in Colombia and started my career hoping to become an agronomist, but somehow I ended up as a biologist interested in mammalian ecology. In 2018 I got a CONICET fellowship to study crop pollination at Northwestern Argentina; since then, I have been enjoying asado, mate, empanadas and, of course, the 40 Celsius degrees during Tucuman’s summer.
I built this website to share my work and my general interests outside academic formality.


My current research
My research is focused on the patterns and mechanisms explaining the contribution of wild and managed species to the pollination of blueberries in the NOA. I’m mainly studying: the effect of animal pollination on several productive metrics of the crop; optimal pollination thresholds to maximize blueberry production; individual and population effectiveness of pollinators; and cascading processes affecting pollination service delivery in blueberry crops.


My researsh interest

Crop pollination
Pollination ecology
Mammalian ecology
Functional diversity
Statistics
R programming

I’m interested in understanding how spatial patterns modulate the functional responses of animals and the resulting effect on ecosystem processes and services.


What I like/love

Biking
Reading (Dostoyevski, Garcia Marquez, Sabato, and Vasili Grossman are personal friends)
Asado or BBQ in english (Despite the ethical conflict inside me, I’m a big meat eater)
Dark beer (preferably Stout)
Animals in general, but particularly bats, cats and dogs.
